work.p: The lines on the recto, beginning "Full of wickedness," were never published in Whitman's lifetime. In 1897, these lines, under the title "Of Many a Smutch'd Deed Reminiscent," were included in the "Old Age Echoes" cluster of Leaves of Grass.

On the verso of this manuscript are notes, titled "Poems," describing Whitman's ambition to write a cluster centered on spirituality. The relationship between these notes and Whitman's published work is unknown.

titleStmt.title:
Full of wickedness
and
Poems
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was probably written about 1859, sometime after Whitman changed the name of his draft sequence "Live Oak, with Moss" to "Calamus-Leaves." The cluster on spirituality did not appear as such in the 1860 edition, though Whitman would return to these considerations when he later planned Passage to India as a companion volume to Leaves of Grass.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Full of wickedness
bibl.orgName: Papers of Walt Whitman (MSS 3829), Clifton Waller Barrett Library of American Literature, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

lg.l:
Full of wickedness, I—of
many a smutch'd deed
reminiscent—of worse
deeds capable,

Yet I look composedly
upon Nature, drink
day and night the joys
of life, and await death
with perfect equanimity,

del.l:
Because my love toward for
him I love is tender
and boundless, and his
love for me is tender
and boundless.—

add.l:
Because of my tender
and boundless love
for him I love,
and because of his
boundless love for
me.—

div1.head: Poems.
div1.p:
A cluster, (same style, as of sonnets like, as "Calamus Leaves") of poems, verses, thoughts &c, embodying
☞
religious emotions & thoughts
spirituality, the unknown, the great aspirations of the soul, the idea of justice, divinity, immortality
